title: Between 8 August 2017 and 7 August 2018, how many governments, from among Bahrain, Oman, Qatar, and Saudi Arabia, will have their long term issuer rating downgraded by S&P, Moody's, or Fitch?
preds: The conglomerate will punish only Qatar
Only two not talked about in the financial selections of news no new good new ?

Since 8th August 2017, Bahrain, Oman & Qatar have all been downgraded by at least one credit ratings agency. All three agencies currently assign Saudi Arabia a stable outlook with only a short time to go.
Don't think there's enough time left to downgrade #4 (KSA) barring a massive economic catastrophe
There could be a revision with oil price volatility in play again.

Updating from original forecast at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/670254. Of the remaining time for this question when the original forecast, half has now elapsed.  Not only has a Saudi downgrade not occurred, but neither has there been any "negative outlook" which almost always precedes a proper downgrade.  It would take a major calamity to turn the current "stable outlook" into a full-blown downgrade in only 3 months.

Saudi Arabia's rating affirmed by Moody’s on fiscal consolidation push 
Outlook for the kingdom remains stable, rating agency says

Three nations already have had their long term credit rating down graded.   With oil prices increasing, I dont see further degradation in Saudia Arabi's cash position.   I believe exposure is to the upside on Qatar with its exports of LNG and phosphate.  Bahrain exposure is to the downside due to civil war. Oman's issues are long term structural stability.  Long term this is a risk, but rising oil prices should cover shortfalls in the short term.

Based on the articles above, it looks like a downgrade for Bahrain and Oman is likely. I didn't know you could be downgraded below "junk" but obviously you can if the question is asking. It looks like the lack of cash reserves and relatively limited oil and gas, not to mention lack of a diversified economy, is making Oman and Bahrain vulnerable. Qatar is also in danger of a downgrade. There's no evidence the diplomatic standoff that is currently happening will be resolved any time soon as tensions in the region rise and Saudi Arabia is determined to make Qatar a client state similar to its' other neighbors. Qatar has larger reserves, more cash, and a more diversified economy but the risk remains high.  Saudi is in better shape, it's a larger country with more reserves and more oil. They also are attempting to diversify the economy. However, the risk remains. MBS is inexperienced and there is plenty of evidence that he is not managing the delicate balance between political stability and economic reform with his aggressive posture. He also has Saudi embroiled in a war with Yemen. Wars aren't good for debt rating. Mitigating this forecast is the rising price of oil. However even the most enthusiastic forecasts don't have the price of oil much above $100. I've also adjusted my forecast given what the "crowd" is saying. The vast majority have assigned a 90-95% probability of 3 countries being downgraded, so I didn't want to be too far off of that result. If forecasting in a vacuum I would have assigned a probability of that result around 40% rather than the 83% I ended up penciling in.

Thanks to @dsarin, @SMH5! Reviewing Saudi Arabian prospects in the next 7 months, by looking at the last 10 years' long-term issuer ratings: Moody's: SA downgraded in May 2016.
S&P: SA downgraded in Feb 2016, Oct 2015, and Jul 2007.
Fitch: SA downgraded in Mar 2017 and April 2016. In all cases of downgrades, and in almost all cases of upgrades, there had been a period of a few months of "negative" outlook (or "positive" outlook for upgrades) prior to the rating being down- (or up-) graded.  Currently, all the ratings agencies have Saudi Arabia as "stable", hence a sudden downgrade in the next few months would be unprecedented in the past 10 years. There is a small chance that "stable" may change to "negative" outlook with one or more agencies, and then "negative outlook" may be followed by a downgrade, but the odds of this happening within 7 months are, in my opinion, about 1:30.

Comparing Bahrain against the other Gulf States, there are various measures and forecasts that can be used to determine the growth forecast, current account deficit, and a risk ranking.   Qatar rates the highest on risk assessment in the group.  However it has consistently held positive growth as % GDP compared to other states.  Oman and Saudi Arabia both hold the same level of risk but lower than Bahrain.   Oman, while consistently positive in its growth % GDP, its levels of growth has remained low between 2015 - 2017.  2015 has been the exception for its range at 4.2.  Qatar has the lowest level of risk the group, however, the recent embargo on trade, diplomatic relations and trade relationships in the Gulf will influence growth negatively and increase risk depending on its debt/gdp levels.  It also has a high current account deficit which could increase this year, perhaps into the next couple of years depending on relations with other Gulf states.  Its growth forecast for 2017 is at 3.4.   These dynamics could lead to the exacerbation of external vulnerabilities and put further pressure on growth and other fiscal metrics for Qatar.  At best, Oman seems a reasonable case for further downgrade despite its most recent downgrade to junk by 1 agency.  Exogenous influences, low levels of growth and debt repayment balance relative to foreign exchange reserves make a strong case for an additional downgrade before IFP end date.

Of the four countries listed, all three agencies hold a negative outlook on Bahrain & Oman. Qatar's outlook is 1 negative and 2 negative watch. Saudi Arabia is currently stable but hasn't been adjusted since March 2017. Bahrain has the weakest rating and continues to do poorly. Government debt:GDP increased from 66 to 82%. Oman has very high unemployment (20%). Predicted debt:GDP is expected to rise from 9% to +25% over the next quarter. Qatar is weathering the Saudi-led embargo surprisingly well, though its GDP has declined by -1.5% this year. The embargo will likely continue for several more months and its effects will begin to be felt via increased costs of imports/production. Saudi Arabia is strong but the continued low price of crude oil may threaten its financial stability. US crude production continues to increase while Chinese demand has recently decreased. Similarly, government debt has doubled from 5.8% to 13.1%. It is also making aggressive foreign policy moves, building up its military and actively opposing Iranian influence elsewhere in the region. All these factors may contribute to a downgrade in its credit rating. https://www.wsj.com/articles/oil-prices-lack-direction-after-overnight-slide-1502790318

As per consensus, indeed the rating agencies have a negative outlook for the majority of the listed nations. Chances of a ratings cut goes up proportional to the number of nations listed, so at least 1 will be cut in the near future.

Since this is a surprisingly big question I'm going to take the countries in order.
Bahrain-In the last year all three ratings agencies have downgraded their outlook and Moody's cut their rating two weeks ago. I think it get's cut by an agency in the next year.
Oman-All three agencies are negative and two have already cut their rating this year. I think it get's cut by an agency in the next year.
Qatar-All three agencies are negative with Fitch and S&P extremely negative (negative watch) and one has already cut their rating this year. I think it extremely likely that it get's cut by an agency in the next year.
Saudi Arabia-The outlook is stable for all three agencies, unless the political or economic situation deteriorates sharply I don't see a cut in the next year. Quick note, I hate the ratings system. Not the agencies (although they have problems), nor the idea of ratings (that's how strangers can trust other strangers), but just the whole labeling of tiers. Its confusing and annoying to have to keep referring to Wikipedia. Sorry to rant but I realized researching this question that I may never have another opportunity.
Should be 4 but the stakes market wise can only bear 3.
Oil prices likely won't get below the recent floors.  All of these countries can at least muddle through for another year.

Saudi Arabia's oil IPO should keep them safe. The other three are small and dependent on oil but oil prices appear to be stabilizing. Qatar is the most likely one to slide further if their rift with the rest of the GCC continues.

Low oil prices and political instability, as the major determining factors, have dinged the credit scores of three of the four listed Gulf Council Cooperation states within the past month.  Stability and earning power of the countries are questionable.  Oil prices have stabilized at around $50 per barrel and besides US defense spending, a little banking and foreign aid packages, oil is their only major source of revenue and and oil profits have decreased significantly with no change in sight.
Oman should already have been downgraded and I will be surprised to not see it happen within a year.
